results.title: Drunken angel
results.creator_credit: Akira Kurosawa and Toho Kabushiki Kaisha
results.brief_description: In 1948 the American army of occupation was still in situ in Japan; Toho, one of Japan’s biggest film production houses and producers of the films of Akira Kurosawa, was riven by strikes - the US Army actually dispersed striking union members who had occupied the Toho site. Against such a backdrop, that any film came out of the Toho state is remarkable. That Kurosawa was able to create a contemporary thriller which was allegorical to the condition of the country, a film rich in traditional Japanese imagery and values, highly esteemed by the critics of his own country - is nothing short of miraculous. Toshiro Mifune takes his first lead role in a Kurosawa film (he became a ‘star’ overnight), playing the sleek but sick young gangster who enlists the help of a shabby, alcoholic doctor, the drunken angel of the title. In Japanese with English subtitles.

results.title: Drums of Fu Manchu. Vol. 2
results.creator_credit: John English, William Witney and Republic Pictures Corporation
results.brief_description: Episodes eight to fifteen of this horror/action movie serial. The story line has Fu Manchu (Harry Brandon) in search of the tomb that houses the legendary sceptre of Genghis Khan. His oldest nemesis Sir Nayland Smith (William Royle) stands in his way and creates an adventure that spans from Asia to America. “And with him, comes the thunder of his summons to death -“

results.title: Drugstore cowboy
results.creator_credit: Gus Van Sant, Karen Murphy, Nick Wechsler and Avenue Pictures
results.brief_description: Gus Van Sant’s cynical but never moralistic story about a junkie couple whose domestic life centres on the pursuit of drugs. Matt Dillon and Kelly Lynch are outstanding as a couple of drifters who are not afraid to state their love for the pleasurable highs that drugs offer: compared to the existences of other people they meet in small-town America, they don’t think they are doing so badly. Alternating between the comic and the bleak, “Drugstore Cowboy” reveals the excess and pain of drug addiction but its sharp, cool and irreverent tone never condescends to, or patronises the viewer. Features an hilarious cameo by William Burroughs as a smacked-out priest.

results.title: Driving Miss Daisy
results.creator_credit: Bruce Beresford, Lili Zanuck, Richard Zanuck, Warner Bros Pictures and Zanuck Company
results.brief_description: The funny, touching and totally irresistible story of a working relationship that became a twenty-five year friendship. When Daisy Werthan (Jessica Tandy) crashes her car, her son Boolie (Dan Ackroyd) insists that his mother’s driving days are over. He hires a chauffeur for her, Hoke Colburn (Morgan Freeman) to keep her out of trouble. But feisty Daisy resents the intrusion and she almost drives Hoke crazy with her insistence that she doesn’t need his help. Luckily, Hoke is a very patient man and the pair become the best of friends after 25 years of driving together. Winner of 4 Academy Awards including Best Picture and Best Actress. Screenplay by Alfred Uhry based on his play.

results.title: Drinking
results.creator_credit: Joe Licastro, Floyd Elliott and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: By alternating live-action sequences and animated graphics, the film follows the behavioral and physiological transformations that are directly linked to consumption of alcohol. It shows the short-term and long-term effects on the human body.

results.title: Drummer Hoff
results.creator_credit: Gene Deitch, Morton Schindel, William Snyder and Weston Woods Studios
results.brief_description: This film is a lively folk verse about the building of a cannon called the Sultan. Brightly dressed in full uniform, each soldier brings a part of the remarkable machine. Based on the book by Barbara and Ed Emberly.

results.title: Potter's Song: Art and philosophy of Paul Soldner
results.creator_credit: David Hubbard, Tom Hubbard, Dick Hoffman and Crystal Productions
results.brief_description: Explains the work and philosophy of ceramic artist and educator, Paul Soldner. Shows him demonstrating his techniques he has developed to create his non-functional raku pottery, and discussing the changing course of his ceramic art and its relationship to the environment.

results.title: Potatoes
results.creator_credit: Robert Lang, Roman Bittman and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: This documentary deals with the gradual shift from the family farm, to corporation-run farms, with all the ensuring problems and personal hardship. It is an incisive evaluation of what is happening in North America particularly St Johns Valley of New Brunswick and in world wide agriculture today.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Robert Lang, Roman Bittman and National Film Board of Canada
results.description: This documentary deals with the gradual shift from the family farm, to corporation-run farms, with all the ensuring problems and personal hardship.
